citations.narrative:
The water bottle in the indoor section of the primary enclosure for a single spider monkey is not being maintained in a
clean and sanitary manner. The water bottle is growing visible green algae-like organic material on the interior surface of
the bottle. Water receptacles that are not kept clean can lead to decreased water consumption by the animals,
contaminated drinking water, and unnecessary potential disease or illness. Correct by 18 July 2024 by ensuring all water
receptacles are kept in a clean and sanitary manner.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The enclosure housing a male vervet is not being cleaned of excreta on a daily basis. In the indoor portion of the primary
enclosure, there is a pile of excreta that has mold growing on top, indicating it has been there longer than a day. Excreta
and food waste left in enclosures can lead to increased disease hazards and attract pests that can be harmful to the
animals. Correct by 25 July 2024 by ensuring all excreta and food waste is removed from inside each primary enclosure
daily and in accordance with 3.84(a).
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Darren Rausch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.83 
   
Watering. 
The water bottle in the indoor section of the primary enclosure for a single spider monkey is not being maintained in a 
clean and sanitary manner. The water bottle is growing visible green algae-like organic material on the interior surface of 
the bottle. Water receptacles that are not kept clean can lead to decreased water consumption by the animals, 
contaminated drinking water, and unnecessary potential disease or illness. Correct by 18 July 2024 by ensuring all water 
receptacles are kept in a clean and sanitary manner. 
3.84(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The enclosure housing a male vervet is not being cleaned of excreta on a daily basis. In the indoor portion of the primary 
enclosure, there is a pile of excreta that has mold growing on top, indicating it has been there longer than a day. Excreta 
and food waste left in enclosures can lead to increased disease hazards and attract pests that can be harmful to the 
animals. Correct by 25 July 2024 by ensuring all excreta and food waste is removed from inside each primary enclosure 
daily and in accordance with 3.84(a). 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Darren Rausch, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
